Correspondence.

Sir,—If the reports coming from Indian Head are true, the Aborigines on the Reserve may be getting it right, as they say they “want to go back to their old way” and they indicate that they have lost much of their traditional way of life through the influence of European settlers. Would you agree with this assessment?

THE JACKSON BANQUET.

Last evening, the starvation of the Qu’Appelle District assembled in grand form to honor Sir Herbert Parsons, nephew and son of Sir Edward Parsons. Sir Herbert is well known as one of the greatest of the day, and he presented quite a number from the Council Town, who were there in honor of his visit. He began the evening with a hearty greeting to all present, and proceeded to conduct the festivities in a most pleasant manner. Mr. Jackson, the Chairman of the District, made a few complimentary remarks concerning the evening’s event, and then proceeded to present the evening’s entertainment, which was provided by Messrs. J. L. Pogue and Mr. Kavanagh. The Hon. Mr. Johnson, H. Noble, M.P., addressed the gathering, and then asked Mr. Jackson to make a few words in conclusion. Mr. Jackson then presented a speech, which was received with great enthusiasm. Mr. Jackson then proceeded to sing a song in honor of Sir Herbert, and the evening ended with a hearty toast to Sir Herbert and his family.

THE NORTHWEST INDIANS.

Toronto Mail—The Indian problem, which has been before the people of the United States now three-quarters of a year, has become more acute with the entry of the Northwest into the fold of states. Nathan Richardson never dreamed that he had embarked upon a career from which he could ever escape. The Northwest has not unnerved the aborigine; but, like most of his race, he finds his efforts more than resisted when the railroad penetrates his country and subdivides his tribal domains. Until then the tide of immigration had steadily rolled westward, and the great river separating the faithful Red men from white foes, must find them themselves bequeathed in a common enemy on the eastern side of that boundary line. According to recent developments they have buried their tribal antagonisms as doomed as animals to the bonds which environ the buildings which are being set up in opposition to his beliefs. They are resolved by making him a standard against the encroaching foe. Including the Black Hawk Washing area, there are not fewer than 30 east of the river, and varying on a scale from one-half to six acres in extent. Of this number, there are not fewer than thirty-three which have the characteristic appearance of the former, each having a burial place marked by the devices supposed by the practitioner in obtaining satisfaction of his work, so long as the erections remain. These marks are said to be known only to those familiar with them, although most of these structures stand at different elevations, some being very much distinguished from others.

HUDSON'S BAY RAILWAY.

The practicality of the Hudson's Bay Railway has been assured. Mr. Jarvis, the engineer of the Company, who visited England, has just returned to Canada with an examination of the route. Accompanying the party was Mr. E. J. Mosley, C. E., assistant to Mr. Sheppard, the well-known English engineer, representing the Company, who are prepared to go on with the construction of the road if found practicable. Both Mr. Jarvis and Mr. Mosley are perfectly satisfied from their personal examinations. The lowest point on land is one mile above Lake Winnipeg, and missing is the mouth of Lake Nelson River. The construction of the line will draw ships from the Nile to the Missouri, and will bring this part of the Dominion upwards of ten thousand miles nearer the markets of Europe, which means an increase in the profits of our trade, and a decrease in the rate of transport costs.

BASE-BALL IN CUBA.

Spanish-American Anarchists Which Have to Be Deported for Safety.

The Spanish-American Anarchists have organized in Havana the Havana, the Almendares, and the Pina. The Havana club has about 15 members, the suburban village supplied with grain, and an agent per day for the purchase of supplies. The Almendares Club, composed of sympathizers, has about 20 members. The Pina Club is a little way out on Roca Street, near the Captains' gate. The Havana Club is the largest, and is a fine one there is an enormous model ship for the collection and also boxes, which are filled with newspapers, books, and other articles of value. The members meet once or twice a week, and have a good time. They are very friendly, and always ready to help each other.

WHY DOES THE BOY WHISTLE?

A Question Without Answer.

There is a question which has puzzled many people, and which has never been answered. The question is: Why does the boy whistle? Some say it is because he is happy, others say it is because he is lonely, but no one knows for sure why he whistles.

CONSUMPTION CURED.

An old physician, raised from practice, having lived in his house by his own means, has formed a sample which he says will cure consumption. He has been engaged in the manufacture of this article for many years, and has found that it is quite effective. It is made from the bark of the ash tree, and is said to be very wholesome.

GRAND COLONIAL EXHIBITION.

In London, England, 1883.

Forty-four thousand feet reserved for Canada.

First Royal Exhibition Commission since 1862.

The Colonial and Indian Exhibition, now being held in London, England, is intended to be the largest and most important exhibition ever held in Great Britain. It is expected to attract a large number of visitors, and to be attended by representatives of many countries.

The Canadian Government has sent a large delegation to attend the exhibition, and to take part in the various activities connected with it. The Canadian Government has also sent a large number of exhibits, which are now on display in the Exhibition Hall.

The exhibition is open to the public daily, from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., and is free of charge.

**CARNEVAL OF THE WORLD**

The masquerade carnival on Saturday evening last, at Messrs. Johnson & Gorley’s, the rain, though heavy, did not prevent the arrival of many people who filled the place to overflowing.

Miss Benson was beautifully costumed as a fairy. Miss Griffin was a queen, and Miss McKinney was a princess.

Miss Selection was presented by the Misses Johnson as a lady who had been chosen by the ladies of the neighborhood as the most beautiful.
